mn11:2.1: The Shorter Discourse on the Lion’s Roar
mn11:3.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn11:3.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
mn11:4.1: “‘Only here is there an ascetic, and a second, third, and fourth ascetic.
mn11:4.2: Other sects are empty of ascetics.’
mn11:4.3: This, mendicants, is how you should rightly roar your lion’s roar.
mn11:5.1: It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say:
mn11:5.2: ‘But what is the source of the venerables’ self-confidence and forcefulness that they say this?’
mn11:5.6: “There are four things explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the Perfect One, the fully awakened Buddha. Seeing these things in ourselves we say that:
mn11:5.7: ‘Only here is there an ascetic, and a second, third, and fourth ascetic.
mn11:5.8: Other sects are empty of ascetics.’
mn11:5.10: We have confidence in the Teacher, we have confidence in the teaching, and we have fulfilled the precepts.
mn11:5.11: And we have love and affection for those who share our path,
mn11:6.1: It’s possible that wanderers who follow other paths might say:
mn11:6.2: ‘We too have confidence in the Teacher—our Teacher—we have confidence in the teaching—our teaching—and we have fulfilled the precepts—our precepts. And we have love and affection for those who share our path,
mn11:6.4: What, then, is the difference between you and us?”
mn11:7.2: ‘Well, reverends, is the goal one or many?’
mn11:7.3: Answering rightly, the wanderers would say:
mn11:7.4: ‘The goal is one, reverends, not many.’
mn11:8.1: ‘But is that goal for the greedy or for those free of greed?’
mn11:8.2: Answering rightly, the wanderers would say:
mn11:8.3: ‘That goal is for those free of greed, not for the greedy.’
mn11:9.1: ‘It is for the hateful or those free of hate?’
mn11:10.1: ‘It is for the delusional or those free of delusion?’
mn11:11.1: ‘It is for those who crave or those rid of craving?’
mn11:12.1: ‘It is for those who grasp or those who don’t grasp?’
mn11:13.1: ‘Is it for the knowledgeable or the ignorant?’
mn11:14.1: ‘Is it for those who favor and oppose or for those who don’t favor and oppose?’
mn11:14.3: ‘It’s for those who don’t favor and oppose.’
mn11:15.1: ‘But is that goal for those who enjoy proliferation or for those who enjoy non-proliferation?’
mn11:15.2: Answering rightly, the wanderers would say:
mn11:15.3: ‘It’s for those who enjoy non-proliferation, not for those who enjoy proliferation.’
mn11:16.1: Mendicants, there are these two views.
mn11:16.2: Views about being reborn and views about not being reborn.
mn11:16.3: Any ascetics or brahmins who cling, hold, and attach to a view about wanting continued existence will oppose a view about extermination of existence.
mn11:16.4: Any ascetics or brahmins who cling, hold, and attach to a view about extermination of existence will oppose a view about wanting continued existence.
mn11:16.5: There are some ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand these two views’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape. They’re greedy, hateful, delusional, craving, grasping, and ignorant. They favor and oppose, and they enjoy proliferation.
mn11:16.6: They’re not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress.
mn11:16.7: They’re not freed from suffering, I say.
mn11:16.8: There are some ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand these two views’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape. They’re rid of greed, hate, delusion, craving, grasping, and ignorance. They don’t favor and oppose, and they enjoy non-proliferation.
mn11:16.9: They’re freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, crying, pain, sadness, and distress.
mn11:16.10: They’re freed from suffering, I say.
mn11:17.1: There are these four kinds of grasping.
mn11:17.3: Grasping at sensual pleasures, views, precepts and observances, and theories of a self.
mn11:17.4: There are some ascetics and brahmins who claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping.
mn11:17.5: But they don’t correctly describe the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping.
mn11:17.6: They describe the complete understanding of grasping at sensual pleasures, but not views, precepts and observances, and theories of a self.
mn11:17.8: Because those gentlemen don’t truly understand these three things.
mn11:17.9: That’s why they claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping,
mn11:18.1: There are some other ascetics and brahmins who claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping,
mn11:18.3: They describe the complete understanding of grasping at sensual pleasures and views, but not precepts and observances, and theories of a self.
mn11:18.5: Because those gentlemen don’t truly understand these two things.
mn11:18.6: That’s why they claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping,
mn11:19.1: There are some other ascetics and brahmins who claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping,
mn11:19.3: They describe the complete understanding of grasping at sensual pleasures, views, and precepts and observances, but not theories of a self.
mn11:19.5: Because those gentlemen don’t truly understand this one thing.
mn11:19.6: That’s why they claim to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping,
mn11:20.1: In such a teaching and training, confidence in the Teacher is said to be far from ideal.
mn11:20.4: and love and affection for those sharing the same path are said to be far from ideal.
mn11:20.6: It’s because that teaching and training is poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, announced by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha.
mn11:21.1: The Realized One, the Perfected One, the fully awakened Buddha claims to propound the complete understanding of all kinds of grasping.
mn11:21.2: He describes the complete understanding of grasping at sensual pleasures, views, precepts and observances, and theories of a self.
mn11:21.3: In such a teaching and training, confidence in the Teacher is said to be ideal.
mn11:21.6: and love and affection for those sharing the same path are said to be ideal.
mn11:21.8: It’s because that teaching and training is well explained and well propounded, emancipating, leading to peace, announced by a fully awakened Buddha.
mn11:22.1: What is the source, origin, birthplace, and root of these four kinds of grasping?
mn11:22.4: And what is the source, origin, birthplace, and root of craving?
mn11:22.6: And what is the source of feeling?
mn11:22.8: And what is the source of contact?
mn11:22.10: And what is the source of the six sense fields?
mn11:22.12: And what is the source of name and form?
mn11:22.14: And what is the source of consciousness?
mn11:22.16: And what is the source of choices?
mn11:23.1: When that mendicant has given up ignorance and given rise to knowledge, they don’t grasp at sensual pleasures, views, precepts and observances, or doctrines of a self.
mn11:23.2: Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.
mn11:23.3: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
mn11:24.1: This is what the Buddha said.
mn11:24.2: Uplifted, the mendicants approved of what the Buddha said.
